title: Three-Place Predicates
goal: Use `dunda` and `cusku` with all three places filled correctly.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Two-place practice — translate to Lojban:

1. I see you.         → ?
2. Bob hears Alice.   → ?
3. Do you meet Tom?   → ?

(Answers: mi viska do, la .bob. cu tirna la .alis., xu do penmi la .tam.)

New Material (5-7 min)

Three-Place Gismu

mi dunda la plise la .bob. — I give an apple to Bob.

Three-place gismu have a giver/doer, a thing, and a recipient. Today you'll learn two essential ones.

Two New Gismu

Lojban Place Structure English
dunda x1 gives x2 (gift) to x3 (recipient) give
cusku x1 says x2 (statement) to x3 (audience) say, express

Using dunda (Give)

The structure: giver gives gift to recipient

Lojban x1 x2 x3 English
mi dunda la plise la .bob. I apple Bob I give an apple to Bob.
la .alis. cu dunda ti mi Alice this me Alice gives this to me.
do dunda la gerku la .tam. you dog Tom You give a dog to Tom.

Common error: Getting x2 and x3 backwards.

  • ✓ mi dunda la plise la .alis. — I give an apple to Alice.
  • ✗ mi dunda la .alis. la plise — I give Alice to an apple. (wrong!)

Using cusku (Say)

The structure: speaker says statement to audience

Lojban x1 x2 x3 English
mi cusku ti do I this you I say this to you.
la .bob. cu cusku ta mi Bob that me Bob says that to me.
do cusku ti la .alis. you this Alice You say this to Alice.

Note: x2 is what is said — often ti (this) or ta (that) as a placeholder for the actual content.

Partial Filling

You don't have to fill all places:

Lojban Meaning Places filled
mi dunda la plise I give an apple (to someone). x1, x2
la .bob. cu cusku ti Bob says this (to someone). x1, x2

The unfilled places are understood as "unspecified."

Key Point

Three-place gismu have a doer (x1), a thing (x2), and a recipient (x3). Order matters — x2 is what's given/said, x3 is to whom.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Translation (Lojban → English)

  1. mi dunda la mlatu la .alis.
  2. la .bob. cu cusku ti mi
  3. do dunda la plise la .tam.
  4. la .meris. cu cusku ta do
  5. mi dunda ti la .bob.
Answers
  1. I give a cat to Alice.
  2. Bob says this to me.
  3. You give an apple to Tom.
  4. Mary says that to you.
  5. I give this to Bob.

Exercise 2: Translation (English → Lojban)

  1. I give a dog to Tom.
  2. Alice says this to Bob.
  3. You give an apple to me.
  4. Bob gives this to Alice.
  5. I say that to you.
Answers
  1. mi dunda la gerku la .tam.
  2. la .alis. cu cusku ti la .bob.
  3. do dunda la plise mi
  4. la .bob. cu dunda ti la .alis.
  5. mi cusku ta do

Exercise 3: Error Correction

Find and fix the error:

  1. ✗ mi dunda la .bob. la plise (I give Bob to an apple)
  2. ✗ la .alis. cu cusku mi ti (Alice says me to this)
Answers
  1. ✓ mi dunda la plise la .bob. (I give an apple to Bob)
  2. ✓ la .alis. cu cusku ti mi (Alice says this to me)

Exercise 4: Create Five Sentences

Write 5 three-place sentences using dunda or cusku:

Example answers
  1. mi dunda la plise do
  2. la .tam. cu dunda la gerku la .meris.
  3. mi cusku ti la .alis.
  4. do dunda la mlatu la .bob.
  5. la .bob. cu cusku ta la .tam.

items.answer: I give a cat to Alice.
You give an apple to Tom.

items.text: I give a dog to Tom.
You give an apple to me.
✗ `mi dunda la .bob. la plise` (I give Bob to an apple)
items.answer: ✓ `mi dunda la plise la .bob.` (I give an apple to Bob)

items.text: ✗ `la .alis. cu cusku mi ti` (Alice says me to this)
items.answer: ✓ `la .alis. cu cusku ti mi` (Alice says this to me)

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "I give an apple to you." → mi dunda la plise do
  2. "Alice says this to Bob." → la .alis. cu cusku ti la .bob.
  3. "Do you give this to me?" → xu do dunda ti mi
  4. "Bob gives a cat to Mary." → la .bob. cu dunda la mlatu la .meris.

Today's Vocab

Lojban Place Structure English
dunda x1 gives x2 (gift) to x3 (recipient) give
cusku x1 says x2 (statement) to x3 (audience) say

Summary

You learned two three-place gismu: dunda (give) and cusku (say). Both follow the pattern x1 does-something-with x2 to x3. Remember: x2 is the thing (gift/statement), x3 is the recipient.

Tomorrow preview: You'll learn zo'e — a placeholder that lets you skip a place when you want to leave it unspecified.
